snippet.textDisplay: A government run business is struggling to be profitable... I am shocked. That's never happened before in history. All state run businesses have record breaking profits each year. And countries where the state runs everything like North Korea, Cuba and the Soviet Union are the most successful and richest in the world :) Jokes aside, Amtrak is another example why there shouldn't be state owned businesses. It's very difficult to do the necessary steps to profitable and to appease politicians at the same time.

And countries where the state runs everything like North Korea, Cuba and the Soviet Union are the most successful and richest in the world :) Jokes aside, Amtrak is another example why there shouldn't be state owned businesses. It's very difficult to do the necessary steps to profitable and to appease politicians at the same time.

snippet.textDisplay: Idk why my state of FL doesn't invest in high-speed lines? Our east (Jacksonville - Miami) and west (Tampa - Ft. Myers) coasts are extremely population dense and follow a relatively straight line, with one dense middle city (Orlando), that could be used to connect them (I'm sure Disney/Universal wouldn't mind). We also have lots of tourists, snowbirds, and old people that really don't need to be driving, as well as tons of commuters, who would fill seats several times/week. Lastly, FL is all flat, so the only construction trouble I could think of is that our state is just one giant sinkhole. Other than that, I can't think of a better place in the US to implement high-speed lines (Besides the NE sector which seems to be covered).

snippet.textDisplay: Ironically the whole reason why Amtrak was created in the first place to save long distance trains in the United States-because they were operated private railroad companies and were losing money!
snippet.textOriginal: Ironically the whole reason why Amtrak was created in the first place to save long distance trains in the United States-because they were operated private railroad companies and were losing money!

snippet.textDisplay:
How profitable would Delta have been if airports themselves were not state funded and if every square yard of runway had to be purchased at a fair market rate from urban centers? Every form of transportation is taxpayer subsidized to one extent or another. Insisting Amtrack cover all its costs would be akin to insisting that there should be toll booths on sidewalks.

Edit: did Richard Anderson entirely divest from the airline industry so no one can construe him as having a conflict of interest and perverse incentive to take out a Delta competitor?
snippet.textOriginal:
How profitable would Delta have been if airports themselves were not state funded and if every square yard of runway had to be purchased at a fair market rate from urban centers? Every form of transportation is taxpayer subsidized to one extent or another. Insisting Amtrack cover all its costs would be akin to insisting that there should be toll booths on sidewalks.

Edit: did Richard Anderson entirely divest from the airline industry so no one can construe him as having a conflict of interest and perverse incentive to take out a Delta competitor?

snippet.textDisplay: I was going to say that the U.S. should only have a single freight mover. Scheduling could be a lot more flexible with only one freight caryer. But after a forced merger resulting with Penn Central I'm not sure that's a good idea, government mergers don't have the best outcome.
